body:
I dont have access to create new repo in [Fluo-io](https://github.com/fluo-io). Can somebody create it then I will add all common resources there.
The parent POM which is used by incubator-fluo an fluo-reciepies is [Fluo-parent](https://github.com/fluo-io/fluo-io-parent/blob/master/pom.xml) not [Fluo project pom](https://github.com/fluo-io/resources/blob/613cf66b7894e9f376b6263a4a6ced8326e3e8dc/pom.xml)

Few questions:
Q1:  There are some of the resources which are in Apache Parent Pom but there configurations are different from what we use. For example: apache-rat-plugin, maven-enforcer-plugin there are many such plugins.
I've migrated the old `fluo-io-parent` to the new `fluo-parent` branch, so it preserves history from that, to get you started.

I think one way we can/should simplify this is that we eliminate any bundled dependencies from our binary distribution. Instead, we can provide a script, or some documentation on what additional libraries they need to add to their classpath to get things working. This reduces the burden on us significantly to maintain legal stuffs, while (at least in the case of the script) minimally impacting users, and at the very least, reduces risk of making bad assumptions about what user already has and what they need us to bring for them.

Eliminating bundled dependencies means we only have to worry about licence/notices for stuff in our project, because that's all we'd be distributing.
+1 other than the class name, this looks good.

I will do changes in new branch of fluo-io-parent repo and will do changes in that branch.
As Keith pointed out that 

> We were planning on releasing the Fluo project pom to Sonatype because we have not transitioned that project to Apache yet

So, Is there a need to change the **distributionManagement** in new parent pom also or can we use apache distribution management. 
Because when we are using apache as parent pom it has its own distributionManagement name so if we again specify distributionManagement in new parent-pom file it will override apache
distributionManagement.

@ctubbsii are you thinking that we will release the pom in https://github.com/apache/incubator-fluo/commits/fluo-parent through Apache?  I guess that could be the first release we make as an incubator project.
@keith-turner Yes.
What need to be done in this task ?

It sounds like @keith-turner's original point might have been more targeted to reducing the scope of dependencies, but it would also be prudent to take a look through all of the dependencies to ensure that they are compatible with the Apache Software License.

See the following pages on [disallowed licenses](http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-x) and [licenses whose code may only be redistributed in binary form](http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#category-b) for the ASF licensing requirements.

@Garvit244, thanks taking this issue on!  Great work so far. Below are some more notes from my review:
- `distributionManagment` should no longer be configured to publish to Sonatype.  This might be able to just be removed if this is configured in the Apache parent and is inherited.
- The organization section could be updated to be the ASF:

```
  <organization>
    <name>The Apache Software Foundation</name>
    <url>https://www.apache.org</url>
  </organization>
```
- I think the developers section could be removed
- The `mailingLists` section could be updated using info on [this page](http://incubator.apache.org/projects/fluo.html)
- The `scm` section should be updated to something like below (i set tag as `fluo-parent` but I could be wrong):

```
  <scm>
    <connection>scm:git:https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator-fluo.git</connection>
    <developerConnection>scm:git:https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf/incubator-fluo.git</developerConnection>
    <tag>fluo-parent</tag>
    <url>https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=incubator-fluo.git</url>
  </scm>
```
- The `url` in `issueManagement` could be updated to `https://github.com/apache/incubator-fluo/issues`
Are any changes to the Type Layer critical? I already created a branch in Fluo recipes that moves out the Type Layer code.
Additional sections which need updating (or deletion): organization, developers, mailingLists, scm, issueManagement, distributionManagement.
For the mailing lists section, you can model it after the same section Accumulo's POM https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/rel/1.7.2/pom.xml#L51

@Garvit244 What I was thinking for this task was to run `mvn dependency:analyze` look at the output for each module and determine if dependencies need to be added or removed from the poms. As for the comment about optional, I am not sure exactly what I was thinking about there.

@joshelser I think what you suggested may be covered by #690?

> Are any changes to the Type Layer critical? I already created a branch in Fluo recipes that moves out the Type Layer code.

I added the Apilyzer plugin to the pom to ensure the public API only uses other public API types.  It found some places in the type layer that violated this.  To fix it I changed those methods to package private or private. It would be good to carry these changes forward to Fluo Recipes.
Did all changes made in review comments.
Thanks @Garvit244. I'll merge in your changes, and then we can do any further cleanup (as needed) from there.

@Garvit244 If you don't mind, I'm actually going to do a pull request against your branch, with a few additional changes I'd like to see. Then, when you update your branch, it'll update this PR, and we can merge in both yours and my changes all at once.

I ran`mvn dependency:analyze` to check unused dependencies in modules pom. There are some of the dependencies which are used but undeclared

```
Used undeclared dependencies found:
 org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-common:jar:2.6.3:compile
Unused declared dependencies found:
 org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client:jar:2.6.3:compile
```

Is these `org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-common` dependency is subpart of `org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client`

Yes, hadoop-common is a dependency of hadoop-client.  We can rely on hadoop-client to bring in this dependency so it doesn't need to be included on its own in our pom. If you run `mvn dependency:tree`, you can verify this and see where other dependencies are coming from:

```
[INFO] +- org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client:jar:2.6.3:compile
[INFO] |  +- org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-common:jar:2.6.3:compile
```

Hadoop client is a virtual (probably not the correct word) dependency that was created to make using hadoop eaiser.  I don't think it has any code associated with it.  I think it just points to all of the other hadoop client libs. 

Since it has no code, mvn dependency analysis thinks we are not using it.   However I think using hadoop client is the correct thing to do.  Using hadoop client will correctly set the version of hadoop common.

https://repo1.maven.org/maven2/org/apache/hadoop/hadoop-client/2.7.2/hadoop-client-2.7.2.pom

Yeah, this is one of those unusual scenarios where the best practice isn't the right thing to do. Best practice says we'd exclude the unused client, and include the used common jar explicitly. Unfortunately, the way Hadoop packages its artifacts, it makes stronger guarantees about the client jar (as a virtual/meta-dependency) and what classes/packages will be included (either directly, or transitively) than it does about the common jar.

So, for Hadoop, at least, the right thing to do is to depend on the client jar and not common.

Point Taken. Will keep client as dependencies in pom.
After doing `mvn dependency:analyze` there were few jars like`slf4j, hdrhistogram, curator-recipes`whcih were unused so removing them. I also checked they were not used anywhere in project by running `mvn clean:install`

+1

The changes you made look good.  I ran the following command to look for anything that may have been missed, but didn't see anything.

``` bash
$ find . -type f | grep -v '/.git' | grep -v '.png' | xargs grep org.apache.fluo | grep -v 'package org.apache.fluo' | egrep -v 'import.*org.apache.fluo' | grep -v '<groupId>'
```

> @joshelser I think what you suggested may be covered by #690?

In part. The other half is a double-check that all dependencies are compatibly licensed with the ASLv2. I assume that was already the case (as fluo was already licensed as ASLv2), but it would be prudent to double check now that we're at the ASF.
I will look into this.

I ran the following command to see what Fluo is importing.

``` bash
find . -name "*.java" | xargs cat | grep 'import ' | grep -v 'import org.apache.fluo' | grep -v 'import static org.apache.fluo' | grep -v 'import java' | sed 's/import //' | sed 's/[.][A-Za-z0-9]*[;]//' | sort -u
```

I found the source code has the following dependencies.   I looked up the license for each dependency. ASF legal docs mention [multiple licenses](http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html#mutually-exclusive)

| Direct Dependency | License |
| --- | --- |
| logback | As of release 0.9.18, logback source code and binaries are dual-licensed under the EPL v1.0 and the LGPL 2.1, or more formally |
| jcommander | ASLv2 |
| codahale metrics | ASLv2 |
| guava | ASLv2 |
| accumulo | ASLv2 |
| commons configuration | ASLv2 |
| commons io | ASLv2 |
| curator | ASLv2 |
| hadoop | ASLv2 |
| log4j | ASLv2 |
| thrift | ASLv2 |
| twill | ASLv2 |
| zookeeper | ASLv2 |
| easymock | ASLv2 |
| junit | EPLv1 |
| org.mpierce.metrics.reservoir.hdrhistogram | BSD 2-Clause |
| slf4j | MIT |

Looking at Fluo Recipes imports, its currently has the following dependencies.

| Direct Dependency | License |
| --- | --- |
| kryo | New BSD License |
| guava | ASLv2 |
| gson | ASLv2 |
| accumulo | ASLv2 |
| commons collections | ASLv2 |
| commons lang | ASLv2 |
| commons io | ASLv2 |
| spark | ASLv2 |
| junit | EPLv1 |
| slf4j | MIT |

Some useful links

http://www.apache.org/dev/licensing-howto.html
http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html
#690 is related to this issue

This was fixed in PR #687 - See this line in the [commit](https://github.com/apache/incubator-fluo/commit/6fd86298c7d6c4759df98e9d6633fe91ec036f99?diff=split#diff-342e5554e01b6078b1ac5c74f973f5d4L105).  This issue should be closed.

Wow, great work here @keith-turner!

> logback   As of release 0.9.18, logback source code and binaries are dual-licensed under the EPL v1.0 and the LGPL 2.1, or more formally

This one would fall into the Category-B licenses which that page you linked describes. Essentially, as long as you are only bundling logback in binary form, you're fine. We may not copy logback source into Fluo.

The rest of these also look fine (BSD and MIT are compatible). It's also worth mentioning that if Fluo only creates a source release, we don't need to do anything else for the first release (L&N don't need anything additions). Only if Fluo also wants to ship some extra artifacts in addition to the required source release do we get into maintaining multiple versions of L&N. Remember that this also applies to jars that get deployed to nexus, not just a "binary tarball" like Accumulo does.

If you're content, so am I. We can check off the first item under "Verify distribution rights" on http://incubator.apache.org/projects/fluo.html too.

>  Only if Fluo also wants to ship some extra artifacts in addition to the required source release do we get into maintaining multiple versions of L&N.

As @ctubbsii  suggested in #690 we may end up with a binary tarball that only contains the Fluo jars and helper scripts for downloading other jars.   In that case we may not need to do anything with L&N.  That's not what we currently have though.  I am kinda leaning towards moving in that direction, it saves us work and makes it clear that dependency versions are really only recommendations.

> we may end up with a binary tarball that only contains the Fluo jars and helper scripts for downloading other jars. In that case we may not need to do anything with L&N

Ok, as long as Fluo doesn't have any source code copied from other projects, I agree with you.

>  That's not what we currently have though. I am kinda leaning towards moving in that direction, it saves us work and makes it clear that dependency versions are really only recommendations. 

I will wait on marking off the checklist at least until we get a first release out. I'm all for knocking off these items, but I want to make sure that it's representative of what we actually release in the end.

Thanks again!

I think commons config can be removed from all poms except for the api module.  I experimented with making that chane in this branch and something really strange happened.  When I ran dependency analyze, it said the following for core.

```
[WARNING] Used undeclared dependencies found:
[WARNING]    log4j:log4j:jar:1.2.16:compile
[WARNING]    commons-configuration:commons-configuration:jar:1.10:compile
[WARNING]    org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-common:jar:2.6.3:compile
[WARNING] Unused declared dependencies found:
[WARNING]    org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client:jar:2.6.3:compile
```

I dont understand why this is happening because core does not directly use commons config.  When I run the following it shows that only API directly uses commons config.

```
$ find . -name "*.java" | xargs grep commons.conf
./modules/api/src/main/java/org/apache/fluo/api/config/SimpleConfiguration.java:import org.apache.commons.configuration.CompositeConfiguration;
./modules/api/src/main/java/org/apache/fluo/api/config/SimpleConfiguration.java:import org.apache.commons.configuration.Configuration;
./modules/api/src/main/java/org/apache/fluo/api/config/SimpleConfiguration.java:import org.apache.commons.configuration.ConfigurationException;
./modules/api/src/main/java/org/apache/fluo/api/config/SimpleConfiguration.java:import org.apache.commons.configuration.ConfigurationUtils;
./modules/api/src/main/java/org/apache/fluo/api/config/SimpleConfiguration.java:import org.apache.commons.configuration.PropertiesConfiguration;
```

Does anyone else know what is going on?

@Garvit244 I see some additional changes that can be made.
- For api module can remove commons collections.
- For integration module can add zookeeper, log4j, and guava at test scope
- For cluster module can add javax inject
- For cluster module can remove fluo-mini and fluo-integration

Still need to figure out whats going on with commons configuration.

For the core module something strange is also going on with log4j.  Its used in the test scope, but dependency:analyze says it need to be added to the compile scope.  I wonder if we added it to the test scope if it would make this warning go away.

Looking at the dependency:analyze documentation I noticed it has a `failOnWarning` options.  I think we should add dependency analyze plugin with this option (configuring it to ignore hadoop stuff) to the Fluo poms.  That will help us keep our dependency declarations correct in the future which will benefit users.  @Garvit244 would you be interested in add this as part of this pull request?  If not I can open an issue and we can add it another pull request.
Sure. I will add that in this pull request and will do all required changes
I was looking at the documentation again and noticed the dependency:analyze plugin has an `outputXML` option.  I gave it a try, its really neat.
I think the version in all of the poms should be changed from 1.0.0-beta-3-SNAPSHOT to 1.0.0-SNAPSHOT.
That's a long subject line for a commit message :) Even GitHub had to wrap it into the comments of the PR.

Since the final release will be `1.0.0-incubating`, I wonder if there's going to be an issue with any version ranges... for example if `-incubating` sorts before, and is treated as "older" than `-SNAPSHOT` by maven.

@keith-turner can you tell me how you check results of these two configuration `outputXML` and `failOnWarning.`
Added this snippet in parent pom code-base :
`<failOnWarning>true</failOnWarning>
              <ignoredDependencies>
                <ignoredDependency>org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-common:jar:2.6.3</ignoredDependency>
                <ignoredDependency>org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client:jar:2.6.3</ignoredDependency>
                <ignoredDependency>org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-mapreduce-client-core:jar:2.6.3</ignoredDependency>
              </ignoredDependencies>
              <outputXML>true</outputXML>`

Running `mvn verify` to check result and its output but getting error.
Removing dependency from cluster module `fluo-mini`throws exception `project fluo-cluster: Unable to start MiniAccumuloCluster: Initialize process returned 1`

> @keith-turner can you tell me how you check results of these two configuration outputXML and failOnWarning.

For `outputXML` I was just thought it was nice to use at the command line when trying to fix the pom.  But I was not thinking it should be in the pom.  Can use it like

```
mvn dependency:analyze -DoutputXML=true
```

For `failOnWarning` , does it cause the build to fail if you comment out one of the `ignoredDependency`? My hope is that it will fail the build if we add a new dependency in code without adding it to the pom.

> Removing dependency from cluster module fluo-minithrows exception project fluo-cluster: Unable to start MiniAccumuloCluster: Initialize process returned 1

Oh, I think I know whats going on there.   That module used to have integration test, but it no longer does. So it used to need MiniAccumulo, but it no longer does.   In addition to removing the `fluo-mini` and  `fluo-integration` can you also try removing the profile with id `<id>mini-accumulo</id>`?  This profile activates the maven-accumulo plugin that runs MiniAccumulo which is not being used.
@ctubbsii, should I change the version prefix to `1.0.0-incubating`? The poms could be `1.0.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT` until its released.
@mikewalch I think that would work.
I set poms to `1.0.0-incubating-SNAPSHOT` and docs to `1.0.0-incubating`.

Dependencies are no longer bundled after the `fetch.sh` script was created for #705 in 9e82f48fa3e0172.

We have a NOTICE file with the text below:

```
Apache Fluo
Copyright 2016 The Apache Software Foundation.

This product includes software developed at
The Apache Software Foundation (http://www.apache.org/).
```

I believe this ticket can be closed.  Does anyone disagree?

> Dependencies are no longer bundled
> I believe this ticket can be closed. Does anyone disagree?

:+1:, gave a quick grep over the code too, and it looks good!

Maybe unrelated (sorry to derail), it looks like the whitespace/formatting on the LICENSE file is off from @keith-turner's original commit f31ce87d. I think it would be nice to have the verbatim copy of the file, although unsure if required (e.g. compare https://github.com/apache/accumulo/blob/master/LICENSE to https://github.com/apache/incubator-fluo/blob/master/LICENSE).
@joshelser, I created the PR #710 to fix the whitespace issue.
Thanks!

> Since the final release will be 1.0.0-incubating, I wonder if there's going to be an issue with any version ranges... for example if -incubating sorts before, and is treated as "older" than -SNAPSHOT by maven.

Ooooppps, @ctubbsii I didn't see this comment before merging.  Just looked at the diffs and merged.   Do you think something needs to be done?

It will fail if any of dependency is used or unused without specifying in pom. One need to add that dependency to `<ignoredependency>` tag. 
If in near future any dependency is added then we can keep track whether that dependency is added in pom or not. This will keep our pom clear and keep track of dependencies.

Q1: `fluo-mapreduce` module uses accumulo-minicluster as dependency for test. Is this dependency needed in fluo-mapreduce pom?
Q2: `fluo-distribution` module `src/main/assembly/bin.xml` assembly descriptor is readed which was failing with error:
`Execution bin-assembly of goal org.apache.maven.plugins:maven-assembly-plugin:2.6:single failed: group id '1493847943' is too big ( > 2097151 ). Use STAR or POSIX extensions to overcome this limit`
@keith-turner, there shouldn't be a problem.  @ctubbsii tested it yesterday and `-incubating` sorts after.
I figured out hoe fluo-core depends on commons config.  Fluo core uses Accumulo's ClientConfiguration class which extends a commons config class.
@keith-turner, can you close this issue as you created it?

> Q1: fluo-mapreduce module uses accumulo-minicluster as dependency for test. Is this dependency needed in fluo-mapreduce pom?

The accumulo maven plugin uses it.   I am not sure what the best way to handle this it.  I tried added the following to `mapreduce/pom.xml`.  This made the plugin ignore mini accumulo just for that module.   The `combine.children="append"` setting was key, I just learned about it from looking at some maven docs.  I am not completely sure I used `combine.children` correctly, but it seems to work.

``` xml
  <build>
    <plugins>
      <plugin>
        <groupId>org.apache.maven.plugins</groupId>
        <artifactId>maven-dependency-plugin</artifactId>
        <executions>
          <execution>
            <id>analyze</id>
            <configuration>
              <ignoredDependencies combine.children="append">
                <ignoredDependency>org.apache.accumulo:accumulo-minicluster:jar:1.7.1</ignoredDependency>
              </ignoredDependencies>
            </configuration>
          </execution>
        </executions>
      </plugin>
    </plugins>
  </build>
```

> Q2: fluo-distribution module src/main/assembly/bin.xml assembly descriptor is readed which was failing with error:

I have no idea whats going on with that error.  I am not seeing anything like that.  Maybe your linux user has a really large group id that it can not handle??
@Garvit244 this looks good.  After the `accumulo-minicluster` ignore is added to the mapreduce pom and the commons config stuff is fixed up, I can merge it.
Done
Note @ctubbsii opened PR garvitbansal/incubator-fluo#1.  However, the combined changes can not be tested (details are on garvitbansal/incubator-fluo#1).
@Garvit244 after those two issues are fixed and the Travis CI build passes, I can merge this.  When I merge it are you ok with me squishing it to one commit? You will still be listed as the author.
@keith-turner sure will do all changes. My Branch has diverged from master also do i need to merge with master first before doing PR.
Now that #690 is done, I think this is done.  Anything else you would like to see done @joshelser?

> Ok, as long as Fluo doesn't have any source code copied from other projects, I agree with you.

Can I get an ACK on this?

> Now that #690 is done, I think this is done.

I believe I would agree with you. Reserve all rights to change my mind when I see rc0 :)

> My Branch has diverged from master also do i need to merge with master first before doing PR.

No, we usually do not merge or rebase until the code review is finished.   Rebasing and merging make it harder for the reviewer to follow changes.   After the code review is done and TravisCI builds successfully, then squash to one commit and push that single commit to master.

> Can I get an ACK on this?

I don't know of any code copied from another project.

> >  Can I get an ACK on this?
> 
> I don't know of any code copied from another project

Great. SGTM

+1  

Thanks @Garvit244 this looks good and the build passed.  You have three commits two of them are merge commits, can you squash this branch into one commit?
Merged into one commit.
Now that the fluo-parent POM has been pushed to the fluo-parent branch, we can proceed updating the master branch to use it.

Nice work @Garvit244 and @ctubbsii.  @Garvit244 if you are still looking for starter issues , #714 may be something to consider.   Also, another way to contribute is by reviewing issues, if you want to review #718 I just made an attempt to use this new parent pom.  Also we will still need to update Fluo Recipes to use the new parent pom
Was merged in ce85675b8824fd2974150be6b5864d9ad57fc8bb
will pick this one
Will start this
I am working on this

> Do you just want a single byte from the array or do you want a section of bytes?

A section of bytes.

Want behavior similar to the following method, except `byte[]` instead of `char[]`.

https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/lang/StringBuilder.html#append%28char[],%20int,%20int%29
Gotcha.
I am going to work on this.

I was wrong about FluoConfiguration supporting this functionality, it does not. Thinking back I think we decided to put the clear options where they are so they could not be put into a config file.  I think the rationale that this would make it less likely someone would inadvertently clear a Fluo instance.  

I am thinking of leaving this as is and updating the Javadoc for InitOpts to state its reason for being.   Also may rename it to InitializeOptions.

@keith-turner https://github.com/cjmctague/incubator-fluo/commit/1a1c7236d34a45e2640268097f28ad990b35f36b

More what you were looking for?
